title: What are the parts of a symphony? - Quora

response.answer_text: I’m assuming you mean the typical movements found in a symphony, as more or less developed by Haydn and modified through present day. It’s usually (not always but often enough to generalize) a four-movement work. In a “classical-era” symphony, the first movement is in “sonata-allegro” (aka “sonata”) form, at a relatively brisk tempo. (Look elsewhere for where this form is described). The second movement was usually a slow one, in sonata or sonatina form. The third was usually a minuet (or Landler) usually in ABA form, and the fourth was a fairly fast one in sonata or sonata-rondo form. The symphonies of Haydn, Mozart and Beethoven tend to conform to this form. When Beethoven wrote his third symphony, it was much longer, on a larger scale than the previous works, yet generally used the same form. At some point a couple of modifications began to be heard: The second movement was (sometimes) the faster one, with the third being the slow, lyrical one. Good example being Mahler’s first symphony, using a funeral march for the third movement. And the “cyclic” idea of themes from previous movements making a reappearance in the last movement was used. A couple of other changes included changing the title of the Minuet movement to “Scherzo”, to be played much faster than the classical minuet, the occasional addition of a fifth movement, the addition of voices to the work, so-called “programmatic” elements (Symphonie Fantastique and others), etc. In general, these didn’t really change the form that Haydn used, just expanded and modified it.

Classical era symphonies are generally in three or four movements using sonata form, variation form, rondo form, etc. at the composer’s preference. The standard of three or four movements characterizes most symphonies but by the 20th century practices began to vary widely. There are one movement symphonies and multiple movement symphonies. The term “symphony” just means “sounding together” but the form has sort of taken on a life of its own.
